results.title: The Golden age of steam: locomotives
results.brief_description: Remember the days of the steam-train and the wonderful sound of the locomotive engine? Then this documentary will take you back in history, to the “golden age of steam”. Produced and filmed in Britain, and containing some rare archival footage, the program presents an historical look at the steam locomotive, including the replica (built in the 1970s) of George Stephenson’s “Rocket”. Also shows examples of such well-known company names as Fenchurch, Stowe, Wainwright and Pennine Ltd which are still running today. Photographed in some of Britain’s beautiful countryside, these locomotives are seen winding through small villages, climbing up steep grades and passing through busy stations. One of the best attributes of the documentary is that it contains minimal commentary allowing the viewer to experience the sound and atmosphere of a bygone era.

results.title: The Foundations of wealth. Part 1. How it all began
results.brief_description: Uses animation and docuemtary footage to establish the concept of living at subsistence level. Shows how vulnerable people are when they need to consume everything they produce in order to survive and points towards the concept of creating a surplus. Suitable for secondary school level.

results.title: The Forbidden forest: a portrait of five teen fathers
results.brief_description: Five young men from Alberta, Canada, talk openly about becoming teen fathers. They discuss the difficulties they face on a range of issues from increased responsibilities, change of life and community attitude to their role as young fathers. The young men discuss how their predicament forced them to address the question of what they want out of life. These young men, accepting their responsibilities, answer questions relating to morals, life choices, youth lifestyle, friendship, jobs, education and career.

results.title: The Five men of Velish: a document from the peoples war in Russia
results.brief_description: A British Ministry of Information propaganda short comprised of silent documentary footage of Russian civilians gearing up to fight Nazi invaders, accompanied by patriotic British narration and rousing orchestral score. The chilling centrepiece is a series of still photographs taken by a German soldier of the execution of five Russian villagers from the town of Velish.

results.title: The Fighting Gunditjmara
results.creator_credit: Rob Brow and Rob Brow Productions
results.brief_description: A documentary about an Aboriginal tribe from Victoria, the Gunditjmara. The Gunditjmara are a well known fighting tribe and the fighting spirit is perpetuated by two generations of champion boxers.

results.title: The Face of North Sydney (PC)
results.brief_description: This disc contains over 3,700 photographs, the full text of “Naming North Sydney” (an historical dictionary of place names) and the full text of 24 heritage leaflets. It has been produced by North Sydney Council’s Stanton Library. The Local Studies Collection, from which the photographs are taken is located within the library (234 Miller Street, North Sydney).

results.title: The Electronic telephone
results.brief_description: This short film is about telecommunications, silicon technology, and the E-phone and Bell’s role in its development. The E-phone is the world’s first fully electronic telephone. Chips utilized in it were designed by Bell Northern Research in Ottawa. Northern Telecom makes 256 phones an hour, on one production line alone. As Canada changes, the telephone changes with it and this film includes historical glimpses with a montage of shots from a telephone museum.

results.title: The Duties of a secretary
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the duties of a secretary and shows how they should be carried out to ensure maximum efficiency in the office. Shows correct and incorrect methods of handling a job, the wrong methods being demonstrated in a dream which a young secretary experiences on the eve of beginning a new job.
